H0.text: Supernovas are taken as evidence of the energy that remains in the low‑energy background radiation observed throughout the sky by astronomers.

H1.text: The big bang is the event from which astronomers consider the low‑energy background radiation, found in every part of the sky that they have studied, to be evidence of energy remaining.

H2.text: Collisions of galaxies are the event from which astronomers have taken the low-energy background radiation found in every part of the sky they have studied as evidence of remaining energy.

H3.text: Modern decay of unstable atoms is the event from which astronomers infer that the low‑energy background radiation found in every part of the sky is evidence of remaining energy.

A4.text: According to the Big Bang model, the radiation from the sky we measure today comes from a spherical surface called the surface of last scattering.

A5.text: The CMB spectrum has become the most precisely measured black body spectrum in nature.
